column4: Could someone tell me why Ubuntu decided to go with such an emphasis on Python, rather than traditional C? I mean, even gcc doesn't get installed, while the python interpreter and a million other python libraries get installed even in the server edition?

Could someone tell me why Ubuntu decided to go with such an emphasis on Python, rather than traditional C? I mean, even gcc doesn't get installed, while the python interpreter and a million other python libraries get installed even in the server edition?
core design decision.
Meaning?
meaning a decision was made to encourage the use of Python
Encourage the use of Python? Hmm..any particular reason? Or is just that Mark Shuttleworth simply liked Python over C++?
a number of people prefer it to C. It also helps that our core dev team includes a Python maintainer.
Oh that makes more sense.. so I just guess c/c++ are merely dying away then..
hardly dying.

Hardly dying? So you are then basically saying that while both are given equal importance, Python gets preference and consequently is packaged default with Ubuntu while Gcc is still can be still obtained from the repos..
what was that question/statement?
you need them because glibc depends on them.
they are a specific set of headers that the kernel source provides.
don't worry about headers. Red herring.
I am going to take your word on that. FlannelKing: But are they even there? Perhaps they are present where I installed them from?
you'd enter that data into /etc/network/interfaces. man 5 interfaces
I know .. but man interfaces doesn't have any information for entering the dns details.
as for the dns servers, place those into /etc/resolv.conf
Ah smooth .. thanks a ton man !
that's the X.Org conffile, yes.
ok thank heavens..
